title: The rotational kinetic energy of a rolling object

content.question: A group of students conducts an experiment with an object made of two uniform disks, each of radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and a thin axle. The disks are connected to each other with the axle at their centers and set on a horizontal table as shown in the perspective view above. The object has a mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and total rotational inertia <math alttext="I" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about the axis of rotation as shown. A light string is tied loosely to the axle such that the string exerts a force without wrapping around the axle. Friction between the axle and string is negligible. The string then passes over an ideal pulley and is tied to a block of mass <math alttext="lowercase m equals 1.0 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> the object-block system is released from rest, and the block accelerates downward. In this case, the object rolls without slipping on the table. The coefficients of static and kinetic friction between the object and table are <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="mu sub s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively (a) Two points A and B are marked on the side of the object, as shown in the side view above. State the direction of the acceleration of each point when the pulley has completed one full rotation and point A has returned to its initial height relative to the table. Explain your reasoning.
